history.content:
sorry, just saw this. Both classes give a great introduction to MEMS fabrication, physics, and applications.

ME119 puts more emphasis on the fabrication processes used to make MEMS, and on the mechanical side of things.

In EE147 I teach some fabrication, but spend more time talking about how to make systems with standard commercially-available processes.

I put more emphasis on the electrical/systems side.

You'll learn how to design accelerometers, micromotors, and micro robots.  I don't have the undergrads do projects, but you do have design

homeworks where you use CAD tools for both design/layout and simulation.

I've had several students go on from ee147 and do research projects with me, including a couple who published their research (which means

that I pay for them to fly to a conference and present the work - an all-expenses-paid vacation, except the part where you have to give a 15

minute presentation to hundreds of people from industry and academia)!

Can anyone describe the difference between EE 147 and ME 119? Both are intro to MEMS classes, and from what I can see from the syllabi, ME 119 uses CAD and has projects whereas I don't believe 147 does. But these could just be the same class for different majors / in different departments.

Pretty much, I'm trying to decide on which to take for next Fall since content for both looks cool, so any info on the two classes is appreciated.
history.subject: EE 147 vs ME 119 (MEMS)
